abstracts.cdata!:
While several factors contributed to
            delays in project implementation, educational legislative
            changes were in harmony with proposed educational and
            regulatory reforms. Results were mixed, though generally
            satisfactory. The policy component, to improve efficiency in
            primary education enrollment, as well as resource
            mobilization, was only slightly improved. The management
            development component showed results below expectations, due
            to inadequate staff training and technical support at the
            central and departmental levels. Even though the supply of
            textbooks and educational materials component improved
            somehow the teaching-learning environment, monitoring was
            insufficient. Key lessons learned suggest that: 1) major
            institutional and political reforms often delay project
            implementation, thus project reformulation and timetables
            revision should be taken into account, as well as
            flexibility in project design; 2) projects containing
            educational reform programs should identify measurable
            objectives; 3) monitoring is crucial for an effective
            implementation; 4) management information systems is
            essential for monitoring and supervision; 5) attention
            should be paid to the political dimensions of change which
            impact on educational policy; and, 6) project design
            flexibility would accommodate diversity in educational and
            socioeconomic conditions.
